data.title: TV REVIEW: The taming of the Dragons
data.meta_description: IN A smart little restaurant recently I watched agog as the toddler opposite me was sat down, plied with breadsticks and plugged into an episode of Waybuloo on its personal iPad.
data.text:
Now, many folk may have a lot to say about that.

I will merely observe that one of the delicious pleasures of TV viewing has gone.

TV used to be watched in homes, on sofas, communally.

This meant shows such as Antiques Roadshow were watched in a slightly different way in every household.

In ours, Antiques Roadshow was watched solely to see those smug types who thought they owned Ming vases discovering they owned vintage Argos.

In my friend’s nicer-natured home they tried to guess the date.

As for Dragons’ Den (Sunday, BBC2), some families tried to guess the stake, the percentage and the end result.

Some just enjoyed the glaring.

It was the same across the schedules.

I’m aware, therefore, that not everyone will have watched the last in the current series of Dragons’ Den for the same reasons as me.

I’ll wager I’m not alone though in finding most of this show irrelevant.

A friend of mine used to refer to that other crowd-pleaser, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, as Who Wants To Win A New Conservatory?

She had realised early on that most contestants won themselves 32 grand and went home and that this, over time, was quite dull.

The same has always been true of Dragons’ Den, where backers and pleaders simply shunt numbers about to music.

Will you give me 80 grand for a five per cent stake in my revolutionary biscuit tin concept?

No I’ll give you 50 for 20.

Although the money kind of exists, the business barons might as well be talking about tickets to the Moon.

Even if it all really happens later, we don’t see it, and what we don’t see isn’t there.

The only pleasure in a Dragons’ Den episode lies in seeing a halfbaked idea torn to shreds.

Well, that’s what I’ve always thought... until last night’s finale.

On came a studious-looking chap with a scrappy beard and glasses in a stained lab coat who proceeded to fire puffs of dry-ice smoke at the Dragons.

We waited for them to consume him in fire.

Not a bit of it.

Instead they pleaded for a tiny stake in this young man’s brilliant, wacky science-education concept like puppies after a choc drop.

It was a true delight.

The Dragons stopped harrumphing and grumping for the cameras.

The young genius beamed with shy delight and a point was proved.

Good things really can happen.

Even on TV.

Country Strife: Abz On The Farm (Sunday, BBC2) is a reminder of the same thing.

Mostly.

Enfield-born rapper Abz and his partner Vicky are a lovely pair, putting what seems like a challenging past behind them in pursuit of a much simpler rural existence.

They are not the first to discover that caring for other lives is a way of fixing and strengthening your own.

I wish that was enough to make a TV programme fly.

Of course it isn’t, which is why Abz is forced to stare in childlike wonder at pieces of fruit he’s allegedly never seen before (in Enfield, trust me, you can buy every tuber and berry on the planet).

The set-piece where he smashed up his guitar for kindling was a step too far.

They might be after the Good Life but don’t make this a sitcom.
